title.value: Cognitive Models as Simulators: The Case of Moral Decision-Making
title.justification: The title is explicitly stated at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: Cognitive Models as Simulators: The Case of Moral Decision-Making

extractions.description: This paper explores the use of cognitive models as simulators to train AI systems, particularly in the context of moral decision-making. By using cognitive models instead of human interaction, the authors aim to reduce the cost and time associated with training AI systems. The research leverages reinforcement learning agents interacting with a cognitive model of the Ultimatum Game to study fairness and emotional adaptation.

type.justification: The paper involves empirical testing and simulation using reinforcement learning models and cognitive models (SbEU) in the context of the Ultimatum Game.
type.quote: In this section, we substantiate the idea of cognitive models as simulators in the context of moral decision-making, by having RL agents learn about fairness through interacting with a cognitive model of UG Responder.

name.justification: The study centers around training reinforcement learning agents using cognitive models, focusing on fairness and decision-making strategies.
name.quote: Here, we leverage this idea in the context of moral decision-making, by having reinforcement learning (RL) agents learn about fairness through interacting with a cognitive model of the Ultimatum Game.

name.justification: The paper specifically applies cognitive models to simulate the moral decision-making process involved in the Ultimatum Game.
name.quote: Here, we leverage this idea in the context of moral decision-making, by having reinforcement learning (RL) agents learn about fairness through interacting with a cognitive model of the Ultimatum Game.

name.justification: The use of cognitive models to simulate human interaction is a central theme of the paper.
name.quote: ...having AI systems interact with, and collect feedback from, cognitive models instead of humans...

name.justification: The paper utilizes the Ultimatum Game, a game-theoretical model, to study decision-making.
name.quote: ...having RL agents learn about fairness through interacting with a cognitive model of the Ultimatum Game (UG), a well-established game in behavioral and brain sciences for studying fairness.

name.justification: The SbEU model is described as a cognitive model used for simulating moral decision-making in the Ultimatum Game.
name.quote: Recently, Nobandegani et al. (2020) presented a process model of UG Responder, called sample-based expected utility (SbEU).

is_contributed.justification: While the paper uses the SbEU model, it credits the model to earlier work by Nobandegani et al. (2020) and does not claim it as a new contribution.
is_contributed.quote: Recently, Nobandegani et al. (2020) presented a process model of UG Responder, called sample-based expected utility (SbEU).

is_executed.justification: The SbEU model is actively used in simulations for training RL agents.
is_executed.quote: In this paper, we substantiate the idea of cognitive models as simulators by having RL agents learn about fairness through interacting with a cognitive model of UG Responder.

is_compared.justification: SbEU is used for performance comparison in terms of how RL agents learn in the Ultimatum Game through interaction with this cognitive model.
is_compared.quote: In Fig. 2, we simulate 10 RL Proposers, and report the mean frequency of an offer being made to SbEU Responder over the past trials, for a total of N = 100, 000 trials.
